simulated_ratings.title: The Innocents (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Perfectly tuned, ambiguous ghost story with creeping dread that hits my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: The Uninvited (1944)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classical haunted house melancholy and romance handled with restraint I appreciate.

simulated_ratings.title: The Changeling (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, patient haunting with a grieving core that kept me uneasy.

simulated_ratings.title: Rosemary's Baby (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn paranoia and domestic dread executed with unnerving precision.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Look Now (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grief-soaked atmosphere and unsettling touches left me chilled long after.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wicker Man (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Folk rituals and isolated-community menace make for a richly eerie experience.

simulated_ratings.title: Carnival of Souls (1962)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dreamlike low-budget eeriness that lingers like a bad dream.

simulated_ratings.title: The Legend of Hell House (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Entertainingly nasty and pulpy, if less elegant than my favorite ghost tales.

simulated_ratings.title: Black Sabbath (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Three stylish slices of the supernatural with mood to spare.

simulated_ratings.title: Kill, Baby... Kill! (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gothic village vibes and uncanny child-ghost imagery right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Blood and Black Lace (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek, sinister fashion-house murders with top-shelf atmosphere.

simulated_ratings.title: Eyes Without a Face (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Chilly, poetic horror that balances tenderness and cruelty beautifully.

simulated_ratings.title: Peeping Tom (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A disturbing character study with a queasy intimacy I couldn't shake.

simulated_ratings.title: Kuroneko (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Haunting, elegant vengeance tale with hypnotic mood and tragic undercurrent.

simulated_ratings.title: I Walked with a Zombie (1943)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly spellbinding island gothic with a strong sense of place.

simulated_ratings.title: Cat People (1942)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Suggestive, shadowy romance-horror that thrives on what it withholds.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night of the Hunter (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fairy-tale darkness and relentless menace that still feels potent to me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Third Man (1949)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Winding mystery and atmosphere-rich postwar paranoia that I enjoyed.

simulated_ratings.title: Double Indemnity (1944)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp and cynical, though I connect more with moodier noirs.

simulated_ratings.title: Out of the Past (1947)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic fatalism and tough romance, engaging if not transcendent for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Elevator to the Gallows (1958)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut, domino-fall suspense with a cool, nocturnal vibe.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wages of Fear (1953)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Nerve-shredding tension and grim stakes that had me locked in.

simulated_ratings.title: Green for Danger (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, contained mystery with just enough wartime edge.

simulated_ratings.title: And Then There Were None (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Satisfying closed-circle suspense, even if the mechanics feel familiar.

simulated_ratings.title: The Others (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, slow-burn ghost story with a strong atmosphere-first approach.

simulated_ratings.title: The Orphanage (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Melancholy, emotionally grounded haunting that worked on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Spirited Away (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Transportive, imaginative and tender in the way I love from animation.

simulated_ratings.title: Kiki's Delivery Service (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, empathetic coming-of-age with quietly magical worldbuilding.

simulated_ratings.title: Monty Python's Life of Brian (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, irreverent absurdity that hits my comedic sweet spot without excess.

simulated_ratings.title: Onibaba (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stark, sensual dread and wartime jealousy left me haunted and exhilarated.

simulated_ratings.title: Ugetsu (1953)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A mournful, fog-shrouded fable whose quiet supernatural sorrow really got under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Dead of Night (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, uncanny anthology chills that build a lingering sense of nightmare.

simulated_ratings.title: The Seventh Victim (1943)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Somber, fatalistic mystery with a hushed evil that I found deeply unsettling.

simulated_ratings.title: The Spiral Staircase (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic stormy-night suspense with a delicately oppressive mood I relish.

simulated_ratings.title: The Body Snatcher (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Morbid, shadowy menace and moral rot delivered with grim, satisfying atmosphere.

simulated_ratings.title: Vampyr (1932)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A drifting, dreamlike trance of horror that felt tailor-made for my tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: The Phantom Carriage (1921)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, poetic morality infused with ghostly melancholy that lingered on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Hour of the Wolf (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A feverish descent into creative dread that left me rattled and thoughtful.

simulated_ratings.title: Let's Scare Jessica to Death (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Whispery, fragile terror and ambiguity that seeped in like a bad dream.

simulated_ratings.title: The Other (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pastoral innocence curdling into quiet horror in a way I found chilling.

simulated_ratings.title: Burnt Offerings (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Comfortable haunted-house dread, a bit pulpy but pleasingly oppressive.

simulated_ratings.title: Ghost Story (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Old sins and wintry specters made for a moody, if uneven, shiver.

simulated_ratings.title: The Stone Tape (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cerebral hauntings and cold science prodded a satisfying, creeping unease.

simulated_ratings.title: The Woman in Black (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic, austere ghost-story chills that gripped me with immaculate restraint.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fog (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A coastal campfire tale with lovely atmosphere that I enjoyed more for mood than shocks.

simulated_ratings.title: The Shining (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I sank into its cavernous isolation and steady, maddening dread completely.

simulated_ratings.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock (1975)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic, sun-dazed mystery whose unanswered questions felt deliciously eerie.

simulated_ratings.title: The Devil's Backbone (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sorrowful, human haunting that balanced tenderness and terror beautifully.

simulated_ratings.title: A Tale of Two Sisters (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lushly unsettling family grief spiral that kept me deliciously off-balance.

simulated_ratings.title: Pulse (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Loneliness and technology woven into a chill that felt bleakly contemporary to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Cure (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A slow, hypnotic slide into moral fog that left me disturbed and fascinated.

simulated_ratings.title: Ringu (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spare, cursed dread that worked on me long after the screen went dark.

simulated_ratings.title: The Witch (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Glossy, action-fantasy witch-hunting left me cold and utterly unmoved.

simulated_ratings.title: The Babadook (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grief made manifest with tightly wound, domestic dread I really respond to.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wailing (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sprawling, doom-soaked mystery that gnawed at me in the best way.

simulated_ratings.title: The House of the Devil (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Patient, retro dread that rewards the wait with beautifully controlled terror.

simulated_ratings.title: Scream of Fear (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsome, twisty chillers like this give me a pleasant, old-fashioned shiver.

recommended_movies: The Curse of the Cat People (1944)

simulated_ratings.title: Night of the Demon (1957)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tourneur’s rationalist-cursed dread and stormy English spookiness hit my atmospheric sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ghost of Yotsuya (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tragic kaidan cruelty and moonlit vengeance with hypnotic mood that lingered on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Nosferatu (1922)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Plague-haunted, nightmarish imagery that felt like pure, ancient dread distilled.

simulated_ratings.title: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (1920)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Expressionist nightmare logic and jagged sets gave me a delicious, uncanny chill.

simulated_ratings.title: The Curse of the Cat People (1944)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, imaginative haunt with childlike melancholy I found quietly moving.

simulated_ratings.title: The Queen of Spades (1949)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Frosty fatalism and eerie superstition wrapped in lush, candlelit gloom I couldn’t resist.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ghost and Mrs. Muir (1947)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Winsome, sea-misted romance with a gentle spectral ache, if light on dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Next of Kin (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn Aussie unease and creaking-house paranoia that built to lovely shivers.

simulated_ratings.title: The Last Wave (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ominous natural mysticism and encroaching doom that seeped under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: The Stepford Wives (1975)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Suburban paranoia sharpened to a chilly, controlled dread I savor.

simulated_ratings.title: Repulsion (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic descent into psychic rot that left me rattled and transfixed.

simulated_ratings.title: The Tenant (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Suffocating paranoia and identity slippage with a queasy, lingering chill.

simulated_ratings.title: Suspiria (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Baroque, witchy color-dream whose intoxicating mood outweighed its logic for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Deep Red (1975)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek, night-bound mystery and brutal flashes, carried by atmosphere and sound.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Torture a Duckling (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rural superstition and moral rot woven into a grim, engrossing nightmare.

simulated_ratings.title: Sorcerer (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweaty, grinding ordeal of fate and machinery that kept my nerves taut.

simulated_ratings.title: Seance on a Wet Afternoon (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Domestic delusion and spiritualist obsession played with chilling, restrained intensity.

simulated_ratings.title: Noroi: The Curse (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Methodical, accumulating dread that bloomed into a deeply unsettling web.

simulated_ratings.title: Dark Water (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sodden melancholy and maternal hauntings that pooled into quiet despair.

simulated_ratings.title: Shutter (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Familiar curses, but the photographic hauntings still gave me cold sweats.

simulated_ratings.title: The Innkeepers (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lightly comic boredom curdling into earnest late-game chills I appreciated.

simulated_ratings.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic morgue mysteries and creeping occult touches worked, if a shade neat.

simulated_ratings.title: Personal Shopper (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A hushed, lonely ghost story draped in grief and modern alienation that hooked me.

simulated_ratings.title: A Ghost Story (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A melancholy time-drift that turned haunting into tender cosmic ache.

simulated_ratings.title: The Little Stranger (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Subdued, class-haunted unease I admired more for hush and implication than shocks.

simulated_ratings.title: The Whip and the Body (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sable-draped masochistic gothic with rich candlelit atmosphere I could sink into.

simulated_ratings.title: Castle of Blood (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Midnight-tale sensuality and fatal ghosts spun into satisfyingly morbid gloom.

recommended_movies: Whistle and I'll Come to You (1968)

simulated_ratings.title: Night of the Eagle (1962)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rationalist hubris meeting quietly mounting occult dread is exactly my flavor.

simulated_ratings.title: Viy (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Folkloric vigil and escalating night terrors gave me a rich, uncanny chill.

simulated_ratings.title: The Leopard Man (1943)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Shadowy suggestion and tragedy worked, if a touch slighter than my Lewton favorites.

simulated_ratings.title: Isle of the Dead (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Plague-shadowed superstition versus reason built a dank, suffocating unease I savor.

simulated_ratings.title: Bedlam (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim period cruelty and moral rot engaged me more as mood than outright horror.

simulated_ratings.title: The Devil Rides Out (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Occult duels and ritual menace entertained, if a bit pulp-forward for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: The Gorgon (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsome gothic gloom, though the literal monster undercut the hush I prefer.

simulated_ratings.title: Quatermass and the Pit (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool, cerebral dread with ancient echoes and urban unease hit a sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Ghost Stories (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Patchwork, sensational ghost bits left me cold and craving subtler chills.

simulated_ratings.title: A Dark Song (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Methodical ritual, grief, and mounting dread had me rapt and unnerved.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night House (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Campy sci-fi splicing and broad laughs clashed with the atmosphere I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: The Eclipse (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet grief and spare apparitions stirred a tender, uneasy ache I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Häxan (1922)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Macabre pageantry and sly wit cast a seductive, nightmarish spell on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Paperhouse (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dreamlike melancholy and child’s-eye peril drew me in beautifully.

simulated_ratings.title: The Reflecting Skin (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sun-blasted rural dread and innocence curdling left a long, sour chill.

simulated_ratings.title: Who Saw Her Die? (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mournful giallo tones and creeping menace kept me tensely absorbed.

simulated_ratings.title: Short Night of Glass Dolls (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Oppressive, political nightmare logic unfolded with a pleasingly morbid hush.

simulated_ratings.title: The House with Laughing Windows (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn art and provincial rot flowered into exquisite, suffocating dread.

simulated_ratings.title: The Long Hair of Death (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Candlelit vengeance and gothic sorrow pleased, if a shade conventional.

simulated_ratings.title: Nightmare Castle (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Baroque cruelty and haunted marital rot worked as enjoyable midnight gloom.

simulated_ratings.title: The Horrible Dr. Hichcock (1962)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lurid morbidity and velvet-draped atmosphere gave me delicious shivers.

simulated_ratings.title: Mill of the Stone Women (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Color-drenched curio and macabre museum vibes hit a nicely eerie register.

simulated_ratings.title: Witchfinder General (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober cruelty and folk terror left me bleak and quietly rattled.

simulated_ratings.title: Blood on Satan's Claw (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pastoral corruption and adolescent evil wove a satisfying folk dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Whistle and I'll Come to You (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Austere, rationalist dread and coastal loneliness chilled me to the bone.
